text: (upbeat music)
So again,
my name is Chern-Hooi Lim.
I was born and raised in Malaysia
in a small town called Batu Pahat.
So, at age 17 I left home and came to the US
through an exchange program.
And later that year, I applied to Drexel University
and got into and also awarded the scholarship.
So Drexel is really known for their co-op program
or extensive fellowship,
sorry, internship program,
where I had the opportunity to work in chemical company
like Rohm and Haas, now Dow Chemical.
So we stipend for my co-op and scholarships.
I largely self-financed my own undergraduate,
with some help from the family.
So in 2010,
I attended University of Colorado
under the supervision of Professor Charles Musgrave.
So by the way, it's the same Musgrave
that was mentioned in previous talks, so yeah.
I'd like to thank my advisor, Charles Musgrave.
And also in 2016,
I joined
the Miyake group
for my postdoc in the Chemistry Department at CU Boulder
later at Colorado State University.
So yeah, I had a pretty productive academic career,
published 30 papers including 15 JACS
and the Science publications.
In early 2019, I co-founded "New Iridium"
with a vision to produce chemicals sustainably.
So I love beautiful Colorado
and decided to stay to build my career
and also my family here.
So shown in the picture here
is one of my favorite activities,
climbing up 14,000 feet mountains.
So at this elevation, the view is spectacular
and it can literally take your breath away,
climbing this high.
And my son Damian was born, uh, November 2019.
So he's one of the happiest thing
and spending time with my family.
So traveling has been always a passion before COVID.
So shown here is a picture of our 2018 European trip
to a small town in Italy called Cinque Terre,
by the Mediterranean.
So I play competitive badminton
and this is how I meet friends from around the world
and all walks of life.
So I'd like to get into my PhD work.
So my PhD work really centers on
the chemical reduction of CO2 to fuel.
So by recycling CO2 to fuel,
we effectively close the carbon cycle
and you see, promising solution to global climate change.
So my approach was to use computational chemistry
to really understand the theoretical underpinnings
of catalysis
and that will help me to design better ones.
So the, the reduction in CO2 fundamentally involved
proton-coupled electron transfer steps.
So using pyridine as a model,
first I looked at
the one electron and one proton radical pathway.
And so later looking at two electron pathway
derived from the reduction product of pyridine
which is the hydropyridine.
So, I was able to map out
the entire potential energy surface
through a series of hydride and proton transfer step,
mediated by a proton relay.
From CO2, the formic acid to formaldehyde and to methanol.
So, theory has always been applied
after the fact, after experimental discovery.
So, however I see theory can play a much bigger role
where we can, you know, actually make predictions beforehand
and which will guide experimental outcome.
So yeah, I would like to change that paradigm a little bit.
So therefore, I was eager
to try to prove out my renewable organo-hydride concept
and started a crowd funding.
Having the public donated $6,000 towards this project.
So with some delay in 2019,
finally we got it published in JACS.
So this was a first system
and also an ambiguous system
to show that a renewable organo-hydride
is capable of the reduction of CO2 to formate.
Contrary to previous belief that
only transition metal hydride can do this.
So moving on to my postdoctoral work in the Miyake group.
So, here I acquired new skill sets
in synthetic organic chemistry.
So, Professor Miyake really,
he had a vision of achieving a metal-free ATRP
or atom transfer radical polymerization.
So ATRP is a technique to make polymer
with controlled architectures
and uniform molecular weight for high-end applications.
So, ATRP has been traditionally catalyzed
by Copper(I) species
but however metal contamination can occur
when it cannot be pure, fully purified
and therefore a metal-free organic species
can have the advantage.
In this case, the metal-free species
is an organic photocatalyst
using light as a stimuli.
So here I was able...
so this project really started towards the end of my PhD,
extended into my postdoc.
So here I was able to apply theory first
to actually come up with a number of candidates:
Organic photocatalyst candidates
that we can down-select actually on a computer
and identify a few candidates
to be proved out experimentally.
So this led to the discovery of the Hydrophenazines,
later published in Science.
So, the same approach later, you know,
we applied to discover Phenoxazines,
the Hydroacridines, and Benzoperylenes.
Um, having different redox potentials
for a wide different,
wide ranging of applications.
So, I was also heavily involved in the mechanistic studies.
So for example,
the Dihydrophenazines is really intriguing
because it formed a big dipole moment in the excited states,
observable experimentally by extensive solvatochromism
from red to blue in solvent of different polarity.
(mumbles)
So next is redox reversibility.
So, for a catalyst to be long-lived and turnover
and have many turnover numbers.
So, in the case of those organic photocatalyst,
we have to design a radical cation
that doesn't degrade,
and can turn over the reaction many times.
So, we also look at the new ones
between electron and energy transfer
when a transition metal is involved as a co-catalyst
and how that affects catalysis.
And finally,
I had the honor to work with
Professor Damrauer and his group
to look at how spectroscopy
can look at excited state evolution
from femtosecond to pico
and now ultimately to nanoseconds.
So with that,
we were able to design photocatalyst
with having different triplet yield
from, you know, 5% to 90% for example
and lifetimes of those catalysts are in the milliseconds,
which is very long for an excited state species.
So, later in my postdoc work,
I was involved in extending synthetic applications
of those organic photocatalysts.
How we can make it more useful and do other work?
So, first we look at cross-coupling reactions,
typically applying the pharmaceutical space
and was traditionally catalyzed by Palladium and heat.
However, in this case,
our Phenoxazines can actually work in tandem
with a more abundant Nickel(II) species.
So in this case,
achieving a grand slam cross-coupling
so that Phenoxazine can actually perform
C-N, C-S, C-O and C-C cross-couplings
with the aid of Nickel.
So, we later also made the discovery that
Nickel complexes, by themselves with a photocatalyst
can also undergo direct photo-excitations.
However,
needing a
bluer photons like 365 nanometers.
So, this also suggests an energy transfer mechanism
between Nickel and photocatalyst,
when it was present.
So the reaction really lies,
lies at the, is in simplicity.
So, and here all you need is those in your
aryl halides and some excess amines,
and sprinkle some Nickel(II) salts
and shine light on it.
So, you don't even need to remove oxygen or water.
And in less than one hour,
you get 90% of the C-N cross-coupling products.
So, this was one of the most read JACS paper of the year
when it was first published.
So, secondly is on the Birch reduction.
So, I was fortunate to work with
talented postdocs and graduate students
in the Miyake lab.
So, the Birch reduction, traditionally,
is mediated by alkaline metals
to generate solvated electrons.
However, this has largely precluded its use
in large scale synthesis
(mumbles)
because it's quite dangerous.
So here, we actually came up with Benzoperylenes,
undergo a sequence of two photon-excitation
to generate
the solvated electrons at will
when we shine light on it,
and performing Birch reduction under bench-top conditions.
So, finally "CO2 to methane" work.
So here, we collaborated with a group,
Marc Robert group in France.
So, combining our organic Phenoxazine photocatalyst
and activating their Iron Porphyrin catalyst,
such that we can access different oxidation states
from Iron(III) to Iron(0),
reducing CO2 to methane.
So, at the time of publication,
this was the first precious
metal-free homogeneous photochemical assistance
for such reduction.
So, fast forward to 2019.
So, this is where I'm at right now.
So, in 2019, co-founded "New Iridum, Inc.",
with a vision to, you know,
produce chemicals more sustainably.
So, we are tackling one of the biggest problems
facing humanity today.
Namely global climate change
with excess CO2 accumulated in the air
and in the ocean.
So, we're working on solutions of
how we can convert CO2 to chemicals and fuels,
um, economically.
So. I think the word economical is important
because, um, you know,
this is how you're going to get
a solution to be implemented.
So, we have actually identified a number of candidates.
We actually can have a greener,
both a greener and cheaper solution.
Such that, you know,
it makes sense to implement,
implement it on an industrial scale.
So, we truly believe that photocatalysis offers unique,
unique mode of activation
to produce those chemicals
effectively and cheaply.
So, I'd like to thank the C&EN again for this honor.
Thank you very much.
And I also like to thank my mom and sisters,
my wife and my son, my in-laws,
my co-workers and co-founders in New Iridum
and the Ables family, my host family in Pennsylvania,
my friends at badminton,
the Musgrave group and the Miyake group.
You guys are the pillars to my success.
I really appreciate you guys.
Thank you.
Thank you so much Chern
for telling us about your story.
You mentioned that your company started
in early 2019.
You had your child later that year
and then a little something happened
at the beginning of 2020.
I'm wondering if you could talk to me
a little bit about
the process of trying to start a company amid,
you know, a pandemic where things are shut down,
you know, obviously it's your first company,
but what were the types of, you know,
challenges that you encountered?
Yeah. So yeah,
I think everybody wish
they had the experience to know
how to deal with pandemic.
The last pandemic was a hundred years ago.
So yeah, it definitely was a stressful,
very stressful, you know, time.
(mumbles)
We essentially have to close down for a few months,
not knowing when we're going to open up
and the funding can run dry.
So however, you know,
for entrepreneur, you know,
when you give a lemon, you will make lemonades.
So yeah, we were able to keep the lights on.
So we actually was pivoting,
a pivoting a little bit.
So we actually got an NSF grant
to work on the COVID problems.
So how we can, for example,
work on synthesis of Remdesivir using photocatalysis.
So actually, uh,
it's kind of fortunate as well actually.
Things are better during pandemic for us actually.
And this is,
during pandemic, we actually secured two industrial projects
with two companies.
I guess, those people are staying at home.
Those tech scouts are staying at home.
They have more, they pay more attention
to startup and make deals.
So, um, yeah,
I think it just, it was a hard time
but you know, I'm happy that we,
you know, we got through it and, you know.
Wonderful! Well, thank you for that.
And thank you for the great talks.
